abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a common, congenital, autosomal recessive, metabolic disorder caused by Phenylalanine hydroxylase (<jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic>) variants.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>967 PKU patients from Gansu, China were genotyped by Sanger sequencing, multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification, and whole exome sequencing. We analyzed the variants of <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> exons, their flanking sequences, and introns.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The detection of deep intronic variants in <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> gene can significantly improve the genetic diagnostic rate of PKU. The distribution of <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> variants among PKU subtypes may be related to the unique genetic background in Gansu, China.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusion</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The identification of <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> hotspot variants will aid the development of large-scale neonatal genetic screening for PKU. The five new <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> variants found in this study further expand the spectrum of <jats:italic>PAH</jats:italic> variants. Genotype–phenotype correlation analysis may help predict the prognosis of PKU patients and enable precise treatment regimens to be developed.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>
